Award.AwardTitle: Computational Techniques for Studying Everyday Multiattribute Choice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Everyday choice objects, such as food items, movies, clothes, and consumer goods, can be seen as possessing different attributes or features. Although choices between everyday objects involve attending to and evaluating these attributes, the attributes themselves may be complex and not easily observed by researchers. This project attempts to develop computational techniques to uncover the attributes involved in everyday choice by combining insights from machine learning and statistics with existing theories in decision making research. It offers the possibility harnessing developments in machine learning and data science to advance our theoretical understanding of everyday decision making and, in the process, yield broader impacts by informing and improving implementation of and policy toward important decisions like those concerned with health care or retirement planning.

There are two major components to this project. The first is computational, and involves the use of statistical techniques to recover (otherwise unobservable) attribute representations for real-world choice objects from large-scale user-generated internet data. The second major component is empirical, and involves the use of these recovered attributes, combined with existing multi-attribute decision rules, to study multi-attribute choices between various real-world objects. Overall, the project applies the proposed approach to three domains: movie choice, book choice, and food choice, and for each of these domains, attempts to predict choice probabilities, decision times, and judgments of attribute importance in naturalistic decision problems involving movies, books, and food items, given to participants in the laboratory. In a similar manner, this project uses these domains to test whether behavioral effects such as choice set dependence and reference dependence, established using the types of stylized experiments popular in multi-attribute research, also hold when the objects under consideration are naturalistic and are not described using explicit attribute-by-object matrices. Finally this project uses these domains to study decisions in which the choice sets themselves are stored in memory, and are not explicitly presented to decision makers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to better understand what people know about the world around them and how this knowledge influences their decisions. For this purpose, we adopted novel computational techniques developed by fields such as machine learning and artificial intelligence, and integrated them with existing psychological theories of human decision making. Our research showed that such a hybrid approach can be highly successful at predicting people?s judgments and decisions, including movie and food choice, probability judgment and forecasting the future, perceptions of risk, social judgment involving prejudices and stereotypes, as well as political judgment. Essentially, by knowing what people know about the world, and using this knowledge to make judgments and decisions they way people make judgments and decisions, our models were able to mimic people?s responses with a very high degree of accuracy.

This research also shed light on the psychological biases underpinning everyday judgment. Particularly, as we were able to specify people?s knowledge, we were also able to understand what aspects of this knowledge guided their behavior, as well as the ways in which knowledge depended on news media and social media. Our approach was also able to relate the learning and use of knowledge to established ideas in cognitive psychology, particularly in subfields like memory research. By doing so we combined theories on human decision making with formal models of mental processes, laying the groundwork for an interdisciplinary computational study of human decision making. Due to the interdisciplinary nature of this research, our results were published in leading journals in decision making, cognitive psychology, social psychology, management sciences, and marketing.

Our results can help shed light on effective behavioral interventions for improving judgment and decision making, and subsequently the wellbeing of individuals. Essentially by incorporating knowledge into models of judgment and decision making, we can start to develop tools to remedy the incorrect use of knowledge. The predictive power of our approach implies that we can also identify the settings in which people will make the most judgment and decision errors, and subsequently target these settings in advance. Testing the applicability of such computational interventions is an important topic for future research.

A final benefit of this project involved training young researchers in psychology to use novel methods in machine learning and artificial intelligence research. Overall this project funded one full time postdoctoral researcher and the experiments and miscellaneous academic expenses of numerous graduate and undergraduate students. This implies that the insights developed as part of this project will continue to influence the study of decision making for years to come.
